verb.description: Allow or enable to escape from confinement; set free.
examples: the government announced that the prisoners would be released

verb.description: Allow (something) to move, act, or flow freely.
examples: she released his arm and pushed him aside
growth hormone is released into the blood during the first part of sleep
no details about the contents of the talks were released

noun.description: The action or process of releasing or being released.
examples: a campaign by the prisoner's mother resulted in his release

noun.description: The action of making a movie, recording, or other product available for general viewing or purchase.
examples: the film was withheld for two years before its release

noun.description: The action of releasing property, money, or a right to another.

origin: Middle English: from Old French reles (noun), relesser (verb), from Latin relaxare stretch out again, slacken (see relax).
